review.title: The Effects of Relative Importance of User Constraints in Cloud of Things Resource Discovery: A Case Study
review.abstract: Over the last few years, the number of smart objects connected to the Internet has grown exponentially in comparison to the number of services and applications. The integration between Cloud Computing and Internet of Things, named as Cloud of Things, plays a key role in managing the connected things, their data and services. One of the main challenges in Cloud of Things is the resource discovery of the smart objects and their reuse in different contexts. Most of the existent work uses some kind of multi-criteria decision analysis algorithm to perform the resource discovery, but do not evaluate the impact that the user constraints has in the final solution. In this paper, we analyse the behaviour of the SAW, TOPSIS and VIKOR multi-objective decision analyses algorithms and the impact of user constraints on them. We evaluated the quality of the proposed solutions using the Pareto-optimality concept.
histories: Proceedings of the 9th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Utility and Cloud Computing (UCC 2016) Shaghai, China, December, 2016
review.COMMENTS: Proceedings of the 9th IEEE/ACM International Conference on Utility and Cloud Computing (UCC 2016) Shaghai, China, December, 2016

metadata.title: The Effects of Relative Importance of User Constraints in Cloud of Things Resource Discovery: A Case Study

sections.text: Keywords Internet of Things, resource discovery, multi-objective, optimization, sensor search, multiple criteria decision analysis

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: This year it is as far as never before in the history of the Federal Republic of Germany.

sections.heading: 2. RELATED WORK
sections.text: This year, there has only been one time in history when there has been such a process.

sections.heading: 3. MULTI-OBJECTIVE OPTIMIZATION
sections.text: In many cases, these goals are defined in non-comparable units and have a certain level of conflict between them. In other words, a goal cannot be improved without worsening another goal [15]. In an optimization problem with a goal, this scenario can be illustrated by a user who wants to select a subset of intelligent objects, but also wants to minimize the price and maximize the accuracy of the sensors in that subset. In an optimization problem with one goal, the search space is always well defined. As several conflicting goals must be optimized simultaneously, it is extremely difficult to find a single optimal solution, but rather a set of options with the same quality. The optimal solution is a set of optimal goal conflicts [2]. A multi-objective optimization problem can be described as asminimize {f1 (x), f2 (x), · · · fk (x), where x · the number of functions · k (greater than the decision) (x) is defined by x.

sections.heading: 3.1 Pareto Optimality
sections.text: In the case of a minimization problem, a solution xT is not dominated if there is no x-S, so fi (x) ≤ fi (xT) for each lens = 1, · · ·, k e fi (x) < fi (xT) for at least one of the objectives analyzed [2]. The image of the set of optimal solutions is called the Pareto limit or Pareto curve. The shape of the Pareto front indicates the type of exchange between different objective functions [5]. Each target can be minimized or minimized. The fixed curve represents the set of non-dominated solutions. This figure is the optimal set of Pareto, which is always composed of solutions concentrated in a particular vertex of a viable region.

sections.heading: 3.2 Multiple-criteria decision analysis
sections.text: The MCDA algorithm is designed to support the assessment of decision-making through a set of objectives and criteria by estimating their importance and determining the contribution of each option in relation to a set of criteria. [10] An MCDA problem can be described using an M × N analysis matrix in which the qij element represents the performance of each option according to the cj decision criteria in non-comparable units and scales as represented by Equation 3. An evaluation matrix is used to represent the relative performance of each individual using a normalization function to compare the various criteria.

sections.heading: 4. EVALUATION METHODOLOGY
sections.text: This section describes the research method used in the experiments. We use the evaluation method proposed by Nunes et al. [23] to compare resource discovery algorithms from a search perspective. In this section, we assume that the criteria and user constraints have the same meaning and relative meaning. Furthermore, the ranking of sensors is used as input for the Pareto solutions. Sensor data, user constraints and their relative meaning are used as input for an MCDA algorithm that produces a ranking of sensors.

sections.heading: 5. RESULTS
sections.text: Figure 2 represents the boxplot representation of the ONVGR, around 1000 (Figure 2.a) and 10,000 (Figure 2.b) intelligent objects that take into account two user constraints. In this figure we must suppress the outliers and limit the number of fronts to 200 to reduce the ONVGR value.

sections.heading: 6. CONCLUSION
sections.text: Efficient resource discovery of intelligent objects by meeting a user's dynamic requirements is an open challenge in CoT environments. Integrating context-sensitive calculation and multi-objective optimization has been widely used to support sensor search and selection and to find the best trade-off between the available solution and the constraints imposed. In this paper, we have used a methodology presented in Nunes et al. [23] to evaluate MCDA algorithms and the impact of the relative importance of user constraints on the quality of proposed Smart Object outcomes. In addition, the accumulated results show that the use of relative importance in user constraints does not necessarily improve the quality of the solution offered by an MCDA algorithm and has a greater impact when fewer user constraints are used. Furthermore, the higher number of user constraints reduces the quality of the proposed solution due to conflicts between user constraints. For future work, we will analyze further features related to its distribution and dominance in solutions such as parameters.

The MCDA algorithm are intended to assist the judgment of decision making through a set of goals and criteria, estimating their importance and establishing the contribution of each option regarding a set of criteria [10].
An evaluation matrix is used to represent the relative performance of each q′ ij using a normalization function to compare the different criteria [30].

Although MCDA problems are found in different areas, they often share similar characteristics such as using multiple criteria always form a hierarchy , conflict between the criteria, hybrid nature, uncertainty and their solutions can not be conclusive [31].

The Simple Additive Weight algorithm is one of the most popular MCDA algorithms and is applied in several application domains such as supply chain management, personnel selection problems, project manager selection and facility location selection [1], [26] .

The Simple Additive Weight algorithm is one of the most popular MCDA algorithms and is applied in several application domains such as supply chain management, personnel selection problems, project manager selection and facility location selection [1], [26] .
The SAW algorithm aims to get a weighted sum of the normalized criterion values of each alternative, where the greater value represents the preferred alternative [26].

The Technique for Order of Preference by Similarity to Ideal Solution is another popular MCDA algorithm applied in Supply Chain Management and Logistics, Design, Engineering and Manufacturing Systems, Business and Marketing Management, Health, Safety and Environment Management, Human Resources Management, Energy Management, Chemical Engineering and Water Resources Management [3].
The TOPSIS algorithm aims to choose the options that are closest to the optimal solution and farthest from the negative optimal solution [30].

The VIseKriterijumska Optimizacija I Kompromisno Resenje uses the concept of compromise programming and has been applied in several fields such as location selection, environmental policy and data envelopment analysis [14].
The VIKOR algorithm aims to find the options that are closest to the optimal solution, and also evaluate their individual and group impact [29].
[23] to compare resource discovery algorithms from a quality of search perspective.

The metric used to evaluate the MCDA algorithms is the the Overall non-dominated vector generation ratio (ONVGR) [7] which shows the number of optimal solutions in the Pareto front as a proportion of the number of solutions proposed by the MCDA methods in each front.

The integration between Cloud Computing and Internet of Things, named as Cloud of Things, plays a key role in managing the connected things, their data and services. Most of the existent work uses some kind of multi-criteria decision analysis algorithm to perform the resource discovery, but do not evaluate the impact that the user constraints has in the final solution. In this paper, we analyse the behaviour of the SAW, TOPSIS and VIKOR multi-objective decision analyses algorithms and the impact of user constraints on them. We evaluated the quality of the proposed solutions using the Pareto-optimality concept.
